docs.lead_paragraph: The fairy tale is often thought to be a simple fantasy, a childish portrait of the world with great villainy vanquished and much happily-ever-aftering. The morals are clear, the virtues plain, the causes of evil transparent. Little Red Riding Hood strays. Sleeping Beauty's father is less than generous. Bluebeard's wife is too curious and her family too incurious. But inner beauty is rewarded. Greed is punished. The impulse may be irresistible: seek the simple cause and the blunt lesson. Such efforts are, as Maria Tatar points out in her new book, ''The Annotated Classic Fairy Tales'' (W. W. Norton), part of a tradition of taming the unruly tale. Over time, the brothers Grimm inserted morals in their tales, even eliminating Rapunzel's premarital pregnancy. The 17th-century French writer, Charles Perrault, whose versions of ''Cinderella'' and ''Puss in Boots'' in his ''Mother Goose Tales'' remain standards, believed in showing that ''virtue is rewarded'' and ''vice is always punished.''

headline.main: Into the Woods, Children, for Dark Mysteries, Not Simple Lessons
